questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

 

The patient presents with signs of paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, indicated by the ingestion of a high dose, deranged liver function tests (LFTs), and oliguria. Paracetamol overdose can lead to severe hepatotoxicity and acute liver failure.

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity. It works by replenishing glutathione stores, enhancing non-toxic metabolism of paracetamol, and reducing the formation of harmful metabolites. Early administration of N-acetylcysteine significantly reduces the risk of liver damage and improves outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is used in the management of shock to improve renal perfusion and cardiac output. It is not indicated in the treatment of paracetamol toxicity and does not address the underlying hepatic damage.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in the treatment of certain cholestatic liver diseases to improve bile flow. It does not play a role in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload conditions such as heart failure or renal failure. It does not address the hepatotoxicity caused by paracetamol overdose and is not part of the standard treatment protocol for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome, also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or malfunction of peroxisomes in cells. Peroxisomes are vital cellular organelles involved in several key metabolic processes, including the beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and the alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. In Zellweger syndrome, there is a mutation in the PEX genes responsible for the biogenesis and function of peroxisomes. This mutation leads to the absence of functional peroxisomes, resulting in the accumulation of VLCFAs and branched-chain fatty acids in the body, which can cause severe developmental abnormalities, particularly in the brain, liver, and kidneys. This includes developmental delay, intellectual disability, frontal bossing, mongoloid face (Down’s syndrome)

 

Note –

 

Refsum disease involves a deficiency in phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, which is crucial for the metabolism of branched-chain fatty acids, leading to its accumulation. The clinical manifestations includes retinitis pigmentosa, ichthyosis, and cardiac arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleosomes: Nucleosomes are the basic units of DNA packaging in eukaryotic cells, consisting of a segment of DNA wound around histone proteins. They are not related to Zellweger syndrome or its pathogenesis.

 

Option C. Lysosomes: Lysosomes are cellular organelles containing digestive enzymes that break down waste materials and cellular debris. While lysosomal storage disorders exist, they are not related to Zellweger syndrome, which is specifically a peroxisomal disorder.

 

Option D. Ribosomes: Ribosomes are the cellular organelles responsible for protein synthesis. They are not implicated in Zellweger syndrome, which is associated with defective peroxisomal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is caused by a defect in peroxisomes, leading to the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids and branched-chain fatty acids, which are not properly metabolized due to the lack of functional peroxisomes.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3:1

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Lymphocytes in human circulating blood are approximately 80 to 90 percent T cells, and 10 to 20 percent B cells. The T-cell to B-cell ratio in the normal marrow varies between 4:1 and 5:1, and a significant increase in T-cell numbers was observed in reactive and myelodysplastic states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult is approximately 3:1.

 

Ratio of CD4 to CD8 T-cells is 2:1.

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+

 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

 

  1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: Under which health program, the School Health was combined in the year 2018? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ayushman Bharat program

 

Explanation:

 

In 2018, the School Health program was integrated under the Ayushman Bharat program. This integration involved the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the Ministry of Human Resource Development. Here, School teachers to be made the Health & Wellness ambassadors

 

The program focuses on various health initiatives for school children are –

 

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation,
  • Deworming with albendazole tablets,
  • Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls,
  • Age-appropriate vaccination,
  • Maintenance of electronic health records, and
  • Teaching first aid.
  • Additionally, the program is part of the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karikram (RBSK), targeting the screening of 30 disorders in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia Mukt Bharat program: This program aims to reduce anemia across the population, particularly among women and children, but it is not the program under which the School Health program was integrated in 2018.

 

Option C. Swachh Bharat Mission: This initiative focuses on cleanliness and sanitation across India but is not related to the School Health program integration.

 

Option D. Poshan Abhiyan: This mission targets improving nutritional outcomes for children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not encompass the School Health program's integration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 2018, the School Health program was integrated into the Ayushman Bharat program, involving health and wellness initiatives for school children.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps


Lim's forceps are designed for ophthalmic procedures as well. They are used to hold and stabilize the eye during surgery, particularly during corneal suturing. They have a platform-like, non-toothed tip to hold the delicate eye tissue without causing damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McPherson forceps: McPherson forceps are typically very delicate instruments used in ophthalmic surgery, especially in procedures involving the cornea and the lens, such as cataract surgery. They have very fine tips for precise manipulation of delicate eye tissues.

 

Option C. Artery forceps: Artery forceps, also known as hemostats, are used in various types of surgeries to grasp and clamp blood vessels to prevent bleeding. They are usually not used in ophthalmic surgeries due to their size and the nature of their design, which is intended to handle larger structures than those found within the eye.

 

Option D. SR (Suture Removal) holding forceps: SR holding forceps are designed for the removal of sutures. They have a small, notched tip at one end to grab and hold the suture for easier removal. They are generally not delicate enough for holding eye tissues during ophthalmic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lim’s forceps are specialized ophthalmic instruments used primarily for corneal suturing, featuring a platform-like tip to gently hold eye tissues during delicate procedures.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORDS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19

 

Explanation:

 

CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

 

CO-RADS is a categorical assessment scale used to evaluate pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT scans. Each category reflects the level of suspicion of COVID-19.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO-RADS-0: This category indicates that the CT examination is insufficient for assessment, not that the lungs are normal, which is a common misunderstanding.

 

Option C. Pleural thickening: While pleural thickening can occur in COVID-19, it is not typical or diagnostic of the disease. COVID-19 primarily affects the parenchyma of the lungs rather than the pleura.

 

Option D. Lobar consolidation: Though lobar consolidation may be present in severe cases of COVID-19, it is not typical of the disease, as COVID-19 more frequently presents with peripheral ground-glass opacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

  • The given clinical scenario depicts paralysis of medial 2 lumbricals and palmar interossei which are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve lies behind medial epicondyle, marked as C in the given image.
  • Ulnar nerve supplies Flexor carpi ulnaris & medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm and in hand, it gives motor supply to hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, all interossei and medial two lumbricals.

 

ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  1. High ulnar nerve palsy (Injury proximal to elbow): Paralysis of all muscles supplied ulnar nerve in forearm and hand. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.
  2. Low ulnar nerve palsy (Injury distal one third of forearm): Sparing of forearm muscles, Paralysis of hand muscles. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The structure marked as A is the deltoid tuberosity. Injury to this part is rare. Its superficial location places it at a risk of trauma, fracture, and sequestration.

 

Option B. The structure marked as B is the lateral epicondyle. The lateral epicondyle is usually involved in the lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow i.e., the overuse injury secondary to the eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon.

 

Option D. The structure marked as D is the anatomical neck of humerus. Here, the shoulder joint capsule is attached. Injury to this part is highly uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4th and 5th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

 

Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection that spreads primarily through the feco-oral route, often through contaminated food and water. It is commonly associated with poor sanitation and overcrowded areas, making it prevalent in areas with inadequate food and water hygiene.

 

Key Points about Hepatitis A:

 

  • Transmission Route: Spread through the feco-oral route.
  • Symptoms: Can cause icterus (jaundice) and gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.
  • Risk Factors: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with the virus, especially in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Prevention: Good hygiene practices, proper sanitation, and vaccination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is primarily spread through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child during childbirth, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C: Incorrect. Hepatitis C is mainly transmitted through blood-to-blood contact, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D: Incorrect. Hepatitis D only occurs in those infected with Hepatitis B and is transmitted in the same ways as Hepatitis B, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route

 

Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

 

  • Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors.
  • All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.
  • Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
  • The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process.
  • Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Epinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon binds to glucagon receptors on the cell membrane, which are also G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option D. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) binds to PTH receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Explanation:

 

The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.

 

While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.

 

Pernicious malaria -  (due to heavy parasitization)

 

  • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs

 

Other Options:

 

A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness in performing daily activities. On examination, the clinician asked her to make an 'O' using her thumb and index finger, which she was unable to do. Which of the following muscles is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to form an 'O' using the thumb and index finger suggests a problem with muscles that control flexion of these digits, specifically the flexor pollicis longus, which is responsible for flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx. This muscle is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. The condition described in the question is consistent with anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, which impairs the flexion of the distal phalanges of the thumb and index finger, making it difficult to perform tasks requiring precise pinch or grip, such as buttoning a shirt.

 

In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus are affected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmar interossei: These muscles are primarily involved in the adduction of the fingers (PAD - Palmar Adducts), and they do not play a role in flexing the thumb or index finger. Therefore, they are not related to the inability to form an 'O'.

 

Option B. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in the opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the other fingers. It is not directly responsible for flexion of the thumb or index finger and is innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve. Its dysfunction would affect opposition rather than the ability to form an 'O'.

 

Note an update - Opponens pollicis, a hybrid muscle, as innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve, and commonly by a branch of the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is responsible for the abduction of the thumb, moving it away from the palm. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx, which is necessary to form an 'O'. Thus, its involvement does not explain the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome affects the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles, leading to difficulty in forming an 'O' with the thumb and index finger due to impaired flexion.

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral side

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (away from the midline, or towards the ear). The lateral rectus muscle’s action is essential for lateral gaze. If there is damage to the abducent nerve, the lateral rectus muscle will be paralyzed, leading to an inability to move the eye laterally and resulting in a medial squint (esotropia), where the eye turns inward.

 

To confirm involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards the lateral side. If the nerve is damaged, the patient will be unable to move the eye laterally, confirming the impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior side: Movement of the eye upward (superior gaze) is controlled primarily by the superior rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This is not the movement tested for the abducent nerve.

 

Option B. Inferior side: Inferior gaze (looking down) involves the inferior rectus and the superior oblique muscles, innervated by the oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) respectively. This does not test the abducent nerve.

 

Option C. Medial side: Medial movement of the eye is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement is not used to assess the function of the abducent nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).

 

Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6th cranial nerve)

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis

 

Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: n Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C:06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D: Alopecia areata:

Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is caused by deficiency of:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a characteristic feature of severe rickets, which is caused by vitamin D deficiency. In severe cases of rickets, profound vitamin D deficiency leads to significant hypocalcemia. This low calcium level can cause muscle spasms, including spasm of the larynx, resulting in laryngismus stridulus. The condition is characterized by sudden, brief episodes of stridor (high-pitched breathing sound) due to laryngeal spasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Incorrect. While vitamin A deficiency can cause various health issues, including night blindness and increased susceptibility to infections, it is not associated with laryngismus stridulus or rickets.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Incorrect. Vitamin K deficiency primarily affects blood clotting and is not related to the development of rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes problems with collagen formation, leading to issues like easy bruising and poor wound healing, but it does not cause rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a manifestation of severe rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, resulting in hypocalcemia and laryngeal muscle spasms.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

The specimen shows an ovarian mass with a tuft of hair in a cystic space, which is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma. Key points about mature cystic teratomas include:

 

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors: They contain various types of tissues derived from the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts): Typically unilocular and contain sebaceous material, hair, and sometimes other tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissues.
  • Presentation: Most patients are asymptomatic, but they may present with an abdominal mass, acute pain due to torsion of the ovary, or rarely due to rupture of the cyst.
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is the treatment of choice for mature teratomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature teratoma: These are malignant and contain immature embryonic tissues, often neuroectodermal. They usually occur in younger patients and are more aggressive.

 

Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains mucinous material and does not contain hair or other tissues.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains clear serous fluid and lacks the complex tissues found in teratomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

choices.text: Leydig cells
Sertoli cells
Seminiferous tubules

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

 

Explanation

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

 

  • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sertoli cells: Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.

 

Option C. Seminiferous tubules: Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.

 

Option D. Epididymis: Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

choices.text: 12 hours
24 hours
6 hours

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.

 

TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:

 

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
  • Second knock - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils

 

Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):

 

  1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
  2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
  3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
  4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
  5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
  6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
  7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
  8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
  9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
  10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
  11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TRALI vs TACO: -

choices.text: 3 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets, taken OD
IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

 

The best treatment among the given options is IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets.

 

Severity of Anemia according to Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign,

 

  • Mild – 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate – 7-9 g%
  • Severe – <7 g %

 

Testing and treating Mild and Moderate Anemia:

 

  • If mild anemia OR moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron and folic acid
  • If patient presents late in pregnancy or is unable to tolerate oral iron: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe anemia:

 

  • Hb < 7g%: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • If patient presents late in the third trimester with severe anemia or Hb is less than 5 g%: ADMIT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)

 

Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year

 

6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical local anesthetic used in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proparacaine 0.5%

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is a topical anesthetic commonly used in cataract surgery. It is favored because it is highly effective when applied in the form of eye drops, providing sufficient anesthesia for superficial surgeries like cataract extraction. Proparacaine has a rapid onset of action, typically anesthetizing the eye within five minutes of application. This quick onset is particularly advantageous for surgeries that are short in duration, such as cataract surgery, which generally lasts between 15 to 30 minutes.

 

Moreover, Proparacaine has minimal systemic absorption, which means it has a lower risk of systemic side effects, making it a safe choice for a wide range of patients. These characteristics make Proparacaine the ideal anesthetic for cataract surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine 0.5%: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic but is typically used for longer procedures or in different forms, such as injections for regional anesthesia. It is not commonly used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries due to its longer duration of action and potential for systemic toxicity.

 

Option C. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic, not used as a topical local anesthetic. It is employed for general anesthesia in different surgical contexts, but it is not relevant for cataract surgery.

 

Option D. N₂O (Nitrous Oxide): Nitrous Oxide is also an inhalational anesthetic, primarily used for its analgesic and anesthetic properties in various procedures, but it is not used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is the preferred topical anesthetic for cataract surgery due to its rapid onset, appropriate duration of action, and minimal systemic absorption.

questions.text: What will be the duration of below-knee POP cast applied for the following injury?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6-8 weeks

 

For injuries like the one shown in the X-ray (fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal), the typical treatment involves immobilization using a plaster of Paris (POP) cast. Foot injuries, including fractures of the metatarsal bones, usually require a period of 6-8 weeks to allow for proper healing. This timeframe is standard for most metatarsal fractures, ensuring that the bone has adequate time to heal and regain strength. Specifically, fractures like the Jones fracture (involving the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction) or the Pseudojones fracture (avulsion fracture) are commonly immobilized for this duration.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fractures of the metatarsals, including those at the base of the fifth metatarsal, are typically treated with a below-knee plaster cast for a duration of 6-8 weeks to ensure proper healing.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

 

In the case described above, the neonate had unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, but had normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, and no hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar type 2. The fact that bilirubin levels dropped after treatment with phenobarbital further supports this diagnosis.

 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

 

  • Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- Physiologic (newborn), Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome, Hemolytic
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase (UDPGT) caused by polymorphism. It is more common, affecting 5-10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It presents with a dark liver on gross examination due to the accumulation of pigment, which is not consistent with the findings described.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar type 1: This condition is more severe than type 2 and typically presents with extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to a high risk of kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not respond to phenobarbital treatment, unlike the neonate described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is characterized by clusters of numerous grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

 

Treatment: Foscarnet or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

  • Oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis:

 

  • It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Causative agent: Coxsackie virus. 

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus.

 

 

 

Option C. Impetigo: It is of 2 types:

 

  • Bullous – S. aureus
  • Non-bullous – S. aureus and Streptococcus. Golden-yellow or honey coloured crust seen.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes labialis is identified as condition characterized by recurrent clusters of vesicles on the lips, caused by the herpes simplex virus, and distinguish it from other vesicular or pustular lesions such as herpangina, molluscum contagiosum, and impetigo.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25 Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th edition Page no 2721

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency
Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy using the B12 stores

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and macrocytic anemia. She was given folate 5mg and the blood picture improved. However, the neurologic manifestations were aggravated. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Folate therapy using the B12 stores

 

This is the most likely cause. Folate and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are interconnected in various metabolic pathways. Folate supplementation can correct the hematologic manifestations of a B12 deficiency, but it does not address the neurologic manifestations. In some cases, folate therapy can "mask" the anemia associated with B12 deficiency, potentially aggravating the neurologic symptoms. The correct approach is to identify and treat the underlying B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malabsorption of folate: Malabsorption of folate could lead to a deficiency, but in this case, the patient was given folate (B9) supplementation, and the blood picture improved. This suggests that the issue is not with the absorption of folate but with its utilization.

 

Option B. Treatment with folate unmasking pyridoxine deficiency: While this is a consideration, especially in cases of neuropathy, the patient's symptoms worsening after folate supplementation suggest another mechanism.

 

Option C. Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS: This is not a recognized mechanism. Folate reductase is an enzyme that converts folate to its active form, and CNS deficiency of this enzyme is not a common cause of neurologic manifestations in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid doses over 1 mg may cause aggravation of vitamin B12 deficiency and may precipitate nerve damage.

 

The most likely cause is folate therapy which used up the B12 stores, aggravating the symptoms.

 

Administration of folic acid for patients with macrocytic anemia can partially reverse the hematologic abnormalities associated with vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the neurologic manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency are not treated by folic acid.

questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis, which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.

 

The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.

 

Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: The following graph is most likely to be seen in: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non-competitive inhibition

 

 In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to the enzyme at a site other than the active site (allosteric site), changing the enzyme's shape and function. This binding reduces the enzyme's activity regardless of the concentration of the substrate. The Vmax (maximum rate of reaction) decreases, but the Km (substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax) remains the same.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Competitive Inhibition: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme. As a result, increasing the substrate concentration can overcome the inhibition. This type of inhibition increases the apparent Km (as more substrate is needed to reach the half-maximal enzyme activity), but the Vmax remains unchanged.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the enzyme alone. This leads to a decrease in both Vmax and Km. This type of inhibition is unique in that the inhibitor does not affect the binding of the substrate but inhibits subsequent reaction steps.

 

Option D. Allosteric Inhibition: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site, causing a conformational change in the enzyme that reduces its activity. This type of inhibition does not follow the typical Michaelis-Menten kinetics and cannot be classified purely based on changes in Vmax or Km.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Features of Non-competitive Inhibition

 

  • The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, other than the substrate binding site and the inhibitor has no structural resemblance to substrate and hence, excess substrate does not abolish the inhibition.
  • The inhibitor combines with the enzymes by a covalent bond, which makes the reaction irreversible.
  • The velocity (Vmax) is reduced and the Km value is not changed, because the remaining enzyme molecules have the same affinity for the substrate.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 80-81

questions.text: Oil droplet cataract is seen in?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Oil droplet cataract is characteristically seen in galactosemia. This type of cataract presents as a central oil droplet appearance in the lens, which is a distinctive finding in patients with this metabolic disorder. Galactosemia is a genetic condition that affects the body's ability to process the sugar galactose properly, leading to its accumulation in various tissues, including the lens of the eye, resulting in the oil droplet appearance.

 

 

In galactosemia, early detection and dietary management can help prevent or reduce the severity of cataracts and other complications. The mnemonic to remember this association is that "oil" and "gallons" both start with "gal," linking oil droplet cataract to galactosemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myotonic dystrophy: The cataract seen in myotonic dystrophy is typically a Christmas tree cataract, characterized by multi-colored, glittering, needle-shaped crystals within the lens.

 

 

Option C. Wilson's disease: This condition is associated with a sunflower cataract, where deposits of copper cause a characteristic sunburst pattern in the lens.

 

 

Option D. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetic patients are more likely to develop snowflake cataracts, which are characterized by flake-like opacities within the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil droplet cataract is a distinctive feature seen in patients with galactosemia, a genetic disorder that impairs the metabolism of galactose, leading to characteristic changes in the lens of the eye.

 

Note – Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy seen in - Keratoconus
